Award.AwardTitle: Nano-focused multimodal imaging, control, and interaction dynamics: ultrafast spectroscopy reaching the single molecule level
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Markus Raschke and his group at the University of Colorado at Boulder extend ultrafast spectroscopy and coherent control to the nanoscale. Femtosecond plasmonic nanofocusing on a tip will be used to investigate the ultrafast electron dynamics of single quantum systems (molecules, quantum dots) in non-homogeneous environments. Studying the infrared vibrational dynamics and control via optical antenna coupling will push IR spectroscopy to the homogeneous sample size and single molecule limit. Via the demonstration of nanoscale near-field pump-probe and its extension to multidimensional spectroscopy, the group will gain insight into nano-scale charge and energy transfer in thin films of model molecular semiconductors, phase segregated polymers, and device relevant bulk heterojunction materials.

Imaging methods that can record details below the conventional resolution limit (~200 nm) are needed to study the interplay between intermolecular coupling and morphology that often dictates the function of important natural and engineered multi-component molecular and nano-materials, such as semiconductors. The investigation of the femtosecond dynamics on nanometer length scales provides insight into the mechanisms that determine their structure, charge-, and energy-transfer. That understanding on the nano- and intermolecular scale will ultimately allow for the systematic design of functional materials such as membranes, polymers, or organic photovoltaic systems as well as control of their performance. This highly interdisciplinary research program also provides a broad learning environment for graduate and undergraduate students. As part of this effort, the Prof. Raschke is making the chemical nano-spectroscopy techniques developed broadly available through industry collaborations and at user facilities at National Labs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Molecular materials gain their functionality through molecular self-assembly, order, and phase separation, that control their electron, ion, and energy transport properties. The study of the underlying intra- and intermolecular coupling has long been impeded by difficulties in microscopic imaging with the desired nanometer spatial resolution, ultrafast time resolution, single molecule sensitivity, and orientational and intermolecular spectroscopic specificity. To achieve these goals we have developed, advanced, and applied novel nano-optical imaging techniques based on linear, nonlinear, and ultrafast near-field light matter interaction based on innovative scanning probe optical antenna tips.

In infrared and Raman vibrational nano-spectroscopy and -imaging we used molecular vibrational resonances as reporters of their local chemical environment to image how structure, coupling, and dynamics of molecules relates to the macroscopic material response. In the application of high spectral resolution correlative infrared nano-imaging this allowed us to resolve intermolecular coupling in spatially resolved probing of vibrational frequency shifts associated with molecular scale morphologies in nano-phase separated block copolymers. Similarly, in symmetry selective probing of multiple vibrational resonances molecular orientation and disorder in organic electronic materials could be imaged on the nanoscale, establishing a new technique of optical nano-crystallography in infrared spectroscopy. In the extension to single molecule Raman spectroscopy at low and variable temperature the ultrafast vibrational dynamics, intramolecular coupling, substrate interaction, and conformational heterogeneity could be accessed systematically on the single molecule level and resolving molecular motion ranging from femtoseconds to minutes. As a particular highlight of this project we were then able to extend femtosecond nonlinear optical spectroscopy to the nanoscale. In nano-focusing femtosecond pulses as local probe, we demonstrated a femtosecond time and nanometer spatially resolved movie of the coupled coherent electron dynamics of plasmonic metallic nanostructures, resolving one of the fastest dynamic processes in materials (see figure). With efficient nonlinear frequency conversion in the nanoscale volume of the scanning probe tip based on a new mechanism we simultaneously opened a new regime of nonlinear nano-optics.

With its interdisciplinary nature the project provided for a broad training and both industry and academic career enabling experience for several undergraduate and graduate students and postdocs, with the dissemination of the techniques to industry and national user facilities.

The project broadly advanced chemical nano-imaging to provide for a real time and real space view of molecular and electronic properties and their underlying dynamics. It established novel imaging techniques as enabling tools applicable for systematic imaging, probing, and control of functionality in many catalytic, electrochemical, biological, or photovoltaic systems.
